intro: Chromolaena bangii, commonly known as the false chaff flower, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant has narrow, lance-shaped leaves and produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in clusters. It is often found in tropical and subtropical regions, growing in disturbed soils and open habitats. Chromolaena bangii is sometimes used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
